DOCNAME: CASE OF WIRTSCHAFTS-TREND ZEITSCHRIFTEN-VERLAGSGESELLSCHAFT MBH v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 10 - Freedom of expression -{General} (Article 10-1 - Freedom of expression);Pecuniary damage - award;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is the owner and publisher of the DATE magazine “ ORG ” .

CARDINAL . In its issue CARDINAL of DATE the applicant company published an article about Mr NORP , at that time a member of ORG , and his cohabitee PERSON The article , with the title “ Diary of an escape ” and the subtitle “ Report . Several myths are entwined around PERSON trip to GPE . The reconstruction of a banal reality ” , described the couple ’s flight from GPE in DATE as Mr NORP was suspected of having committed the offences of aggravated fraud ( PERSON ) and fraudulent conversion ( PERSON ) . After an international arrest warrant had been issued , PERSON NORP was arrested in GPE on DATE . At the time of the events , great public interest in the criminal proceedings against PERSON existed . After PERSON arrest , PERSON had given interviews on these events . The article was accompanied by a photo , which appeared on another page , showing PERSON standing beside Mr R.
CARDINAL . The article and its context , namely a short text accompanying photos showing the couple ’s hotel and a bar in GPE , contained the following statements :

“ ... Thus , the NORP mutation of ‘ PERSON and PERSON started on the last part of their trip , a TIME bus ride ... ( Also brach die niederösterreichische Mutation PERSON and PERSON , einer vierstündigen GPE ... auf . )
... DATE , ‘ PERSON and PERSON hardly ever left the hotel ... ( Die ersten ORG verlassen ‘ PERSON praktisch nie . )
... ’Bonnie and Clyde’ from ORG wish to rent the Mayor ’s bar ... ( ‘ PERSON Niederösterreich wollen die ORG pachten . )
... PERSON and PERSON are dreaming of a decent life as pub owners ... ( ‘ PERSON bescheidenen PERSON als Barbetreiber . ) ”
The article , when describing the arrest of PERSON NORP , further stated :
“ C. G. , against whom no suspicion exists , stays behind . ( PERSON bleibt GPE , gegen die nichts vorliegt . ) ”

CARDINAL . On DATE Mrs PERSON brought proceedings against the applicant company claiming compensation for defamation under Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Mediengesetz ) . Further she requested supplementary measures under LAW , such as the publication of the judgment . She stressed that the applicant company , by publishing the article at issue , had committed the offence of defamation under LAW ( Üble Nachrede ) .

CARDINAL . She argued that the comparison with the famous criminals ‘ PERSON and PERSON from DATE , whose story was the basis of a film produced in DATE , could have given the impression that she was also involved in the offences of PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the Wiener Neustadt Regional Court ( PERSON ) dismissed PERSON claim . It found that the average reader would have understood “ PERSON and GPE as a synonym for a couple on the run and that it had been a pictorial description with a humorous and entertaining message . It considered that the average reader would have connected “ PERSON ” with a woman who follows her partner “ through thick and thin ” and that the characterisation as “ PERSON ” did not amount to an accusation of having participated in the offences of PERSON R.

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) quashed this decision and remitted the case to ORG . It observed that “ PERSON and PERSON ” had been violent criminals and found that the established connection between PERSON G. and “ PERSON ” created an “ inherent statement of having participated in criminal acts ” even though “ it had been expressly stated in the article that no suspicion had existed against PERSON G. ” . It , therefore , concluded that the applicant company had committed the offence of defamation under LAW § CARDINAL of LAW ) by publishing the article at issue and stated that its finding had to be taken into account by ORG in its new decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sentenced the applicant company to pay compensation of ORG CARDINAL ( MONEY ) for defamation and to reimburse PERSON costs of the proceedings and ordered it to publish an extract of its judgment in its magazine . Following ORG line of argument it found , referring to the above mentioned passages of the incriminated article , that :

“ ... the well - known movie ‘ PERSON and PERSON described CARDINAL ordinary people who make the NORP dream of liberty and wealth come true by stealing cars , robbing banks and killing people . ( ... ) The reader primarily associates PERSON with a criminal who had , together with her partner , robbed innumerable banks and had killed CARDINAL persons within DATE . ( ... ) Nobody would have connected PERSON only with a naive angel , who followed her partner devotedly but , rather , with a woman who would kill to assist the common purpose ‘ LOC . ( ... ) Beyond doubt the reader is forced to make a connection with capital crime . ( ... ) The allegation of participating in criminal offences constitutes defamation within the meaning of LAW of LAW . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company filed an appeal and stressed , inter alia , that the incriminating passages had to be considered in connection with the article as a whole . It submitted that the article was written in an ironical style and could not have given the impression that PERSON had committed any criminal acts .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal and confirmed ORG decision as a whole .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mrs PERSON applied to ORG for an injunction under Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Urheberrechtsgesetz ) against the applicant company . She requested that the applicant company be ordered to refrain from publishing her picture without her consent in connection with reporting on the criminal proceedings against Mr NORP or , in the alternative , that the applicant company be ordered to refrain from publishing her picture without her consent in connection with referring to her and Mr NORP as “ PERSON and GPE . Furthermore , she requested an order for the publication of the judgment in the applicant company ’s magazine .

CARDINAL . She argued that the publication of her picture in connection with a report on the criminal proceedings against Mr NORP violated her legitimate interests under Section CARDINAL of LAW and that the comparison with the famous criminals “ PERSON and PERSON ” could have given the impression that she had been involved in the offences of which PERSON NORP was accused .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant company , in its observations , argued that the report at issue expressly mentioned that there were no criminal proceedings pending against PERSON and that the report was written in an ironical style and could not have given the impression that PERSON had committed any criminal acts . Moreover , she had willingly given interviews to the media and had her pictures taken by journalists . As regards the comparison of PERSON with “ PERSON ” , the applicant company submitted that the reader of its magazine understood “ PERSON and PERSON ” as a synonym for a couple on the run and not for violent criminals . Finally , it contended that the great public interest in the events justified the publication of PERSON picture .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Wiener Neustadt Regional Court granted an interim injunction ( einstweilige GPE ) . It found the measure justified as the interest in the publication of PERSON picture violated her legitimate interests .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG allowed the applicant company ’s appeal and dismissed PERSON application .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( Oberster Gerichtshof ) partly allowed PERSON extraordinary appeal on points of law and granted the interim injunction she had requested in the alternative , i.e. it ordered the applicant company to refrain from publishing PERSON picture without her consent in connection with referring to her and Mr R. as “ PERSON and GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG observed that Section CARDINAL of LAW prohibited publishing a person ’s picture if the publication violated that person ’s legitimate interests and that the publication of her picture had to be considered together with the content of the published report . The court referred further to its case - law in which it had found that the publication of the picture of a spouse of a suspect was not of any informative value and that the concerned spouse ’s interest in secrecy , therefore , outweighed the interest of information . The court found , however , that in the present case PERSON was far more involved in the case of Mr NORP than simply being Mr NORP ’s cohabitee or girlfriend , as she had prepared the escape with him and had finally escaped with Mr NORP Therefore , the applicant company ’s interest in publishing her picture in principle outweighed PERSON legitimate interests in secrecy .

CARDINAL . The court then argued that the text of the article at issue , compared PERSON with the female partner of the violent criminals “ PERSON and PERSON ” and could give the impression to the readers of the magazine that PERSON as “ PERSON ” had been involved in the criminal offences of her partner . ORG , thus , concluded that , although it seemed that PERSON had consented to the publication of her picture in connection with the criminal proceedings against Mr R. , her legitimate interests were violated by the publication of her photo in combination with a comparison with the criminal “ PERSON ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG granted a permanent injunction prohibiting the applicant company from publishing PERSON picture while comparing her and Mr NORP with “ PERSON and PERSON ” or while connecting her with the commission of criminal offences .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant company ’s appeal and ordered the applicant company to pay PERSON costs of the appeal proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , referring to its decision of CARDINAL DATE , rejected the applicant company ’s extraordinary appeal on points on law . This decision was served on DATE .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides for the strict liability of the publisher in cases of defamation ; the victim can thus claim damages from him . In this context “ defamation ” has been defined in LAW , as follows :

“ CARDINAL . As it may be perceived by a third party , anyone who accuses another of having a contemptible character or attitude , or of behaving contrary to honour or morality , and of such a nature as to make him contemptible or otherwise lower him in public esteem , shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding DATE or a fine ...

CARDINAL . Anyone who commits this offence in a printed document , by broadcasting or otherwise , in such a way as to make the defamation accessible to a broad section of the public , shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding one year or a fine ...

CARDINAL . NORP The person making the statement shall not be punished if it is proved to be true . As regards the offence defined in paragraph CARDINAL , he shall also not be liable if circumstances are established which gave him sufficient reason to assume that the statement was true . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW , in so far as relevant , reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Images of persons shall neither be exhibited publicly , nor in any way made accessible to the public , where injury would be caused to the legitimate interests of the persons concerned or , in the event that they have died without having authorised or ordered publication , those of a close relative . ”

This provision has been interpreted in ORG case - law . In particular ORG has found that in determining whether the publication of a person ’s picture violated his or her “ legitimate interests ” regard is to be had to the accompanying text . Where the publisher of the picture claims that there was a public interest in its publication , the courts have to carry out a weighing of the respective interests involved . As regards reporting on criminal cases , ORG has constantly held that there is no predominant public interest in the publication of the suspect ’s picture if it has no additional independent information value . The only effect is that the intensity of such reporting is increased by attaching the suspect ’s picture and , thus , making his or her appearance known to the public at large ( see ORG v. GPE , no .
